justification: The article discusses that the late posterior positivity (LPP) is proposed as an electrophysiological marker of recollection-based recognition because its amplitude is larger when an item is recognized with high confidence compared to when it is not.
The text mentions that the LPP's sensitivity to memory confidence and source memory makes it a candidate to index recollection-based memory, though it may also reflect decision-making processes.

The study found that the LPP dynamics are sensitive to both recollection-based memory and the evidence accumulation process for recognition decisions, with the LPP amplitude scaling with subjective confidence irrespective of memory signal presence.

The research indicates that the LPP tracks the dynamics of mnemonic decision, with its amplitude building up to a threshold reached at the time of the recognition decision, similar to the centro-parietal positivity (CPP) in perceptual decisions.
